turns.speaker: learner
turns.text: Responding to Feedback or a Performance Review

turns.speaker: learner
turns.text: “Hi, I want to practice responding to feedback or a performance review. So I will set a scenario where I am participating in a feedback session with my teacher about an EDA project that I've done recently about some supplement sale report and I want you to be my teacher giving me feedback, comments, what I should improve and what I did good in my project and I will play the role of a student.”

turns.speaker: bot
turns.text: That sounds great! I’d be happy to help you practice. So, let’s imagine we’re in a feedback session about your exploratory data analysis project on supplements. I'll start by giving you some feedback on what you did well and areas for improvement, and then you can respond as the student. Sound good? Let’s get started!

turns.speaker: learner
turns.text: “Hi, I just submitted my assignment this morning. It is a project about the supplement sales. Could you please share your comments about my visualisation and my code, and my inside interpretation, please?”

turns.speaker: bot
turns.text: Of course! Overall, your visualizations looked really clear, and you did a great job of presenting the data in a straightforward way. One suggestion would be to add a bit more context to some of your charts, like maybe including annotations or more detailed labels. And your code was well-structured, but we can definitely refine some of the functions for efficiency. How do you feel about those points?

turns.speaker: learner
turns.text: “Thank you so much. I can understand why you tell me to improve this point. I will try to refine my code more in the future, but I don't really understand why I should put more annotations on my project. Can you explain me more about it?”

turns.speaker: bot
turns.text: Absolutely! So, annotations help guide your audience through the key insights in your visualizations. They make it easier for someone to understand the main points at a glance, especially if they’re not familiar with the data. So, adding a few notes or highlights can really enhance the clarity of your findings. Does that help clarify it a bit?

turns.speaker: learner
turns.text: “Yes, absolutely. I really appreciate it. So, last time I submitted another EDA project, but I did not explain well and I did not interpret the insight very deep. So, have you seen any improvement in this particular area?”

turns.speaker: bot
turns.text: Yes, definitely! I’ve noticed that your interpretation has become more thorough and clear this time around. You’ve really gone deeper into the patterns and trends, and your explanations are more detailed. That’s definitely an improvement! Keep it up, and I’m excited to see how you continue to grow. Let me know if there’s any other area you’d like more feedback on!

turns.speaker: learner
turns.text: “I really want to receive more feedback on two areas. The first area is my code efficiency, because I know that in real life you don't have much time to write your code, and I don't really want to do byte-coding. I want to write my own code, but sometimes I realize that my code is not very efficient, especially at the first part, the cleaning part. I don't know if I can refine it more.”

turns.speaker: bot
turns.text: Absolutely, that makes perfect sense! In terms of code efficiency, we can definitely look at ways to streamline your data cleaning steps. For example, we can use more efficient pandas functions, or vectorized operations, and avoid loops where possible. We can also look at how you handle missing data and see if there are some shortcuts or best practices you can use. We can definitely dive into that more deeply if you'd like!

turns.speaker: learner
turns.text: “Oh yes, talking about finding missing values, I have a question about dropping columns. Because in my dataset, I found that there are a lot of columns that have missing values, and some of them take up around 40% of the column. So I don't know if we have any criteria or standard to decide when you should drop a column when it misses too many columns, like 20% or 10%.”

turns.speaker: bot
turns.text: That’s a great question! Generally, there isn’t a one-size-fits-all rule, but a common practice is to consider dropping columns if they have a high percentage of missing values, like above 30% or 40%. But it also depends on how important that column is for your analysis. If it’s crucial for your insights, you might consider imputing the missing values instead. So it’s really about balancing the data completeness with the importance of the information. We can definitely explore some criteria and strategies that would work best for your dataset!

turns.speaker: learner
turns.text: “Yes, I really thank you for that. I also want to receive more feedback on my interpretation because I haven't finished my business analysis yet. I want to know how to make my interpretation sound more professional and less clunky. Sometimes I feel like my insight is very straightforward but is not suitable to present it in the business conference context. Could you give me some advices on my writing, please?”

turns.speaker: bot
turns.text: Absolutely, I’d love to help with that! One tip is to focus on clarity and context. When you present your insights, try to link them directly to business objectives or potential impacts. Also, using more precise language and avoiding jargon can help keep your interpretation professional. It can also help to include a few actionable recommendations based on your findings. And of course, practice makes perfect, so we can definitely refine your writing step-by-step. Let me know if there’s a particular section you’d like to work on first!

turns.speaker: learner
turns.text: “Thank you for your advice. I really want to start with generating some actionable...”

turns.speaker: bot
turns.text: That sounds great!

turns.speaker: learner
turns.text: “Inside, yeah.”

turns.speaker: bot
turns.text: Perfect! We can definitely focus on crafting those actionable insights and making sure they’re clear and impactful. Whenever you’re ready, we can dive into some examples or go step-by-step through your findings. Just let me know how you’d like to proceed!

turns.speaker: learner
turns.text: “I found that there is a part where I analyzed a correlation between the discount rate and the revenue of the Zins supplement and I think the correlation rate is is not very clear that they affect each other. So I want to draw the insight from this data that the discount rate have nothing to do with the revenue of Zins. So they should try to improve the quality or they can do all the marketing policy instead of using discount rate.”

turns.speaker: bot
turns.text: That’s a really solid insight! You’re absolutely right that if the correlation is weak, it’s important to highlight that the discount rate might not be the key driver of revenue. Emphasizing that point can help guide the business toward focusing on other strategies, like improving product quality or refining marketing tactics. We can definitely refine how you present that in a professional and clear manner, so it’s impactful and actionable. Let me know if you’d like to work on the wording or any specific part of that insight!

turns.speaker: learner
turns.text: “Yes, thank you for that. I really want to delve into that part. I want to make it sound more suitable for business context.”

turns.speaker: bot
turns.text: Absolutely, we can work on that! We can focus on framing it in a way that highlights the strategic implications. For example, you could say something like, "Our analysis indicates that discount rates do not significantly impact revenue for the Zims supplement. Therefore, the business should consider focusing on enhancing product quality and refining marketing strategies to drive growth." We can polish and refine that wording together, and make sure it’s both professional and impactful!

turns.speaker: learner
turns.text: “Yes, thank you for your advice. I wonder if the writing language and the speaking language at this such context will be similar because I'm worried that my speaking language will affect my writing, my interpretation. So, and vice versa, I don't want to sound too formal at the conference. So, what is your recommendation?”

turns.speaker: bot
turns.text: That’s a great point! In a business conference setting, it’s definitely important to strike a balance. You want to be professional, but also clear and approachable. So, a good approach is to use concise, straightforward language without too much jargon. Also, speaking naturally and confidently will help your interpretation come across as authentic and engaging. We can definitely work on making sure your writing and speaking styles align, so that everything feels cohesive and professional. Just let me know whenever you want to practice or refine a particular section!

turns.speaker: learner
turns.text: “Yes, I really want to work on this section. I wonder if the insight and the presentation in my project will be similar to academic writing.”

turns.speaker: bot
turns.text: That’s a really insightful question! In general, academic writing tends to be more formal and detailed, often with a focus on theory and comprehensive literature reviews. On the other hand, business communication is often more concise, focused on actionable insights, and a bit more approachable. But there’s definitely overlap, and you can absolutely blend the two styles. We can work on making sure that your interpretations are both professional and practical, so they fit well into the business context. I’m excited to help you refine that!

turns.speaker: learner
turns.text: “Yes, I really appreciate your explanation. I understand everything and I will try to improve this particular area in the next project. So I will make the changes and then I will send you the update by Friday.”

turns.speaker: bot
turns.text: That sounds fantastic! I’m really glad to hear that, and I’m excited to see how your next project turns out. Feel free to reach out anytime if you need more feedback or just want to brainstorm. Good luck with the revisions, and I look forward to seeing your updates on Friday! Top of Form Bottom of Form
